title: 'The Art of the Deal' by Donald Trump, or the art of capitalizing on a bestseller
summary: In 1987, the real estate mogul published an autobiography that became a business success manual. The book, ghostwritten by a former journalist who now claims to have fictionalized the negotiations it describes, has become a political strategy handbook for the American president and his supporters.

title: Europe increases pressure on Israel over Gaza offensive
summary: The humanitarian crisis has prompted international anger, with the European Union saying it would review its trade cooperation deal with Israel over the blockade. Meanwhile, the Israeli army stepped up its offensive over the weekend, vowing to defeat Gaza's Hamas rulers, whose October 7, 2023 attack on Israel triggered the current war.

title: Trump unveils $175 billion 'Golden Dome' missile defense program with weapons in space
summary: The new defense system would have the capability of stopping missiles 'even if they are launched from space'.

title: Defeated Romanian nationalist candidate asks court to annul presidential elections
summary: George Simion, who was defeated in Sunday's presidential runoff, announced on Tuesday that he intends to appeal the results and seek the election's annulment, citing alleged 'external interferences,' notably by France.

title: Actor George Wendt, who played beloved barfly 'Norm' on 'Cheers,' dies at 76
summary: The 'doting family man' died peacefully in his sleep on Tuesday morning, according to a family statement. Wendt spent six years in Chicago’s renowned Second City improv troupe before sitting on a barstool at the place where everybody knows your name – and earned six Emmy nominations for best supporting actor from 1984-89.

title: Birthday bones and dog beer: France's growing pet party craze
summary: More and more people are celebrating their pets' birthdays. Often with a sense of self-mockery, they use these canine celebrations as a pretext to socialize with other humans.

title: EU pledges emergency funding for Radio Free Europe after US cuts
summary: The Trump administration had halted US grants to the Cold War-era broadcaster over accusations of liberal bias.

title: What causes the contaminations that led Nestlé to filter its Perrier water?
summary: Nestlé filters water from its Vergèze source to address repeated incidents of chemical or fecal bacteria pollution. These contaminations might be linked to the over-exploitation of aquifers by the world's leading bottled water company.

title: War in Ukraine: Putin dodges Trump threats after another fruitless conversation
summary: The US president did not mention any tightening of sanctions, as advocated by Europeans, but said he hoped for direct negotiations between Russia and Ukraine to discuss peace terms.

title: War in Gaza: EU to reassess trade ties with Israel
summary: The European Union's top diplomat, Kaja Kallas, announced that the bloc will revisit its cooperation agreement with Israel, while the United Kingdom said it is suspending trade talks and sanctioning West Bank settlers amid mounting international condemnation of Israel's war conduct and aid blockade.

title: EU, UK adopt new wave of sanctions against Russia
summary: The latest sanctions against the Kremlin have been in the pipeline for weeks. The EU had already approved theirs last week.

title: France plans to build maximum-security prison in French Guiana, angering local officials
summary: The wing, reserved for drug traffickers and Islamic militants, would form part of a $450 million prison announced in 2017.

title: Musk says he will spend 'a lot less' on future political campaigns
summary: The comments will trigger speculation that the close relationship between Donald Trump and Elon Musk may be shifting as the Tesla tycoon steps away from his full-time role as cost-cutting chief for the US administration.

title: Jim Morrison bust found by chance in France, 37 years after theft
summary: The sculpture of the Doors frontman that once adorned his grave, missing since 1988, was found during a search tied to a fraud case led by the Paris public prosecutor's office.

title: Hungarian parliament approves bill to leave International Criminal Court
summary: In Hungary's parliament on Tuesday, 134 lawmakers voted in favor of the proposal to leave the ICC, while 37 voted against and seven abstained.

title: Showdown between Paris and Pavel Durov
summary: The head of Telegram has accused France of attempting to influence the Romanian presidential election. The French secret service and Ministry of Foreign Affairs have firmly denied the claims.

title: Why did the justice system not 'stop' child abuser Le Scouarnec when he was first arrested, in 2005?
summary: On trial since February 25 for having raped and sexually assaulted 299 people, most of whom were minors, former surgeon Joël Le Scouarnec had already been the subject of an investigation 20 years ago.

title: Nestlé's fraud allegedly netted the industry giant over €500 million
summary: According to a French Sénat inquiry commission, the global food giant profited from its illegal practices between 2022, when it was asked to put an end to them, and 2025.

title: The Marseille police tried to set up a drug lord with 360 kilos of cocaine. The operation ended in total fiasco
summary: The officers of the Marseille Anti-Narcotics Office had hoped to trap Mohamed Djeha, aka 'Mimo,' one of the biggest drug traffickers in France. But the 'monitored delivery operation' turned into a debacle.

title: Ukraine's population is losing hope for a truce as battles intensify
summary: Donald Trump's promises of a quick resolution to the conflict have clashed with the violence of Russian assaults and strikes, which are intensifying on the eastern front.

title: Hungary: Akos Hadhazy, the mastermind behind protests against Viktor Orban's rule
summary: Every Tuesday, the Budapest MP led a protest against corruption and the decisions of the Hungarian Prime Minister's government. He persevered, undeterred, but without finding fault with his opponent, nor any allies to support him.

title: Brussels has been without a government for nearly a year
summary: The presence, or lack thereof, of the separatist New Flemish Alliance in the next government continues to divide negotiatiors and paralyze the regional parliament.

title: French report warns of 'subtle but subversive' spread of Muslim Brotherhood ideology
summary: France must act against the rise of political Islamism, according to a confidential government report warning that the Muslim Brotherhood poses a long-term threat to national cohesion – not through violence, but by gradually eroding secular values at the local level.

title: Pope Leo XIV willing to host Ukraine talks at the Vatican, says Italian PM
summary: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said that Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russia's foreign minister indicated that they would present their terms for a potential ceasefire, 'maybe in a number of days.' Italy's Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni said that Pope Leo XIV was willing 'to host upcoming discussions' at the Vatican.

title: 'Even after Trump's concessions, US tariffs are at their highest since the 1930s'
summary: Donald Trump has backed down to China and offered concessions to the United Kingdom, yet US tariffs have still risen from 2.5% to an average of 14%, analyzes Eric Albert, a journalist at "Le Monde," in his column.
